Welcome



This is a place dedicated to the strange and unique beauty of urban, african art and photography. My eyes are open to the contrasting colors, exotic curves of object, animals, and humans.

Here I am able to venture into my passion of still photography, fashion and urban art. In doing this, I have created a free, international platform, where chosen artist are featured.

I love ♡ colaborations, new artist, compliments, and constructive criticism. Take a trip and discover a new world.

More

What I Do

I walk along dirt paths ⚘, scattered with unusual discared branches and leaves. I run along the highway pumpimg Beyonce ♫ in my ears. Old antique furniture cries for me to restore their beauty, and I answer. Cooking food calms my mind and gives me order. Family ䷤, people in action, sun setting, and historic buildings are captivated by my Nikon digital camera.

My goal is to provide a platform for upcoming artist and photographer. I am baised to individuals who choose to show the beauty of dark skin, curved body attributes ↺ ↻ , natural landscapes, and printed frabrics.

Who I Am

I find freedom in my Nikon camera, vintage sewing machine, frabic, acrylic paint, photoshop, InDesign, dance, music, and my pinterest invoked, crazy DIY projects heheheh....

I love a God ☩, who loves me unconditionally .
Nigerian American woman searching for more knowledge of her culture.
A woman who can make herself smile.
How about you smile with me ☺ ?

My Work

Here is a view of my photography, graphic design, and painting.

Featured Artist: I See A Different You

We as I See A Different You encompass ourselves with the rich history of South Africa through the cultures and documenting of our diverse nation. Our look was inspired by the Pantsula Era which originated in the townships of South Africa during the reign of the apartheid government.

The Pantsula movement which comprised of a distinct style, dress and dance, developed into a form of social commentary and expression for black South Africans and has since undergone several transformations with the country’s change in political tides.

Originally Pantsula’s wore matching outfits for performances which represented unity and self-identity amongst the young men in the group in a time of social division. We fell in love with the style and the culture which lead to us documenting ourselves as Pantsula’s of the Apartheid era during the 1950’s and 1960’s. We morphed the style in order to capture our individual expressions and personalities to match our story.

Kliptown, Soweto // 2014
Africa
Check their Tumblr site here.
